info.game_comments:
Mark Dawson game 2.

New title graphics.

double_jeopardy_round: THEATRE IN THE NEW YORK TIMES

(2, 1).clue: This term for baby frogs means "round head", so their enemies must be Cavaliers

(3, 1).clue: A marriage-minded monster awaits this title creation in a 1935 horror classic starring Elsa Lanchester

(4, 1).clue: In 1964 he introduced his first musical synthesizer; it was used on Walter Carlos' "Switched On Bach" LP

(5, 1).clue: Returning from the Third Crusade, this English "lion" king was kidnapped & held until a huge ransom was paid in 1194

(6, 1).clue: "Hi, cher" isn't necessarily a pop star greeting; "cher" means this endearing term

(2, 2).clue: If you were a Hun in 450 A.D. this man was your king

(3, 2).clue: A dimwitted shut-in becomes the toast of Washington, D.C. society in this comedy starring Peter Sellers

(4, 2).clue: In 1854, he demonstrated his elevator safety device by ascending in an elevator & having the rope cut

(5, 2).clue: Assassin James Earl Ray was arrested in this capital city June 8, 1968 by Scotland Yard detectives

(6, 2).clue: You'll find a "cocodril" on the bayou but it isn't a crocodile; it's this relative

(2, 3).clue: To sing "the home of the brave" in the home of the National League Braves, you have to be in this stadium

(3, 3).clue: As Josef Mengele, Gregory Peck sets out to breed a new race of Hitlers in this thriller

(4, 3).clue: In 1922, he marketed quick-frozen fish, his first packaged frozen food product

(5, 3).clue: This publishing heiress was kidnapped on February 4, 1974

(6, 3).clue: Who was that masked animal?  It was a chaoui, or this creature with 5 or 6 dark rings on its tail

(2, 4).clue: In the Marvel Comics universe it's Tony Stark's alter ego

(3, 4).clue: Bogie stars as Phillip Marlowe in this 1946 film noir classic based on Raymond Chandler's first novel

(4, 4).clue: There was little demand for his revolver until the Mexican-American War when the U.S. government ordered 1,000

(5, 4).clue: Bank robber Clyde Barrow died along with this woman in a 1930s police ambush

(6, 4).clue: Kawasaki knows "laissez les bons temps rouler!" means this

(2, 5).clue: His libretto for the opera "The Devil and Daniel Webster" was based on his own short story

(3, 5).clue: Stanley Kubrick's directorial style in this 1975 movie mimicked the detached manner of 18th century English painters

(4, 5).clue: In 1769, he obtained his first patent, a separate condensing chamber & other improvements to the steam engine

(5, 5).clue: The man who shot Alexander Hamilton in a duel was vice president under this man

(6, 5).clue: "May a pregnant yak chew on your ears for eternity" is a bad example of what Cajuns call gris gris or this

(1, 1).clue: The Times thinks it's fitting that the musical revue "newyorkers" features this statue singing a torch song

(2, 1).clue: When this product was first released in 1944, it carried a picture of an Indian chief & the slogan "Don't be a paleface"

(4, 1).clue: He was known as "The Louisville Lip" & "Cassius the Brashest"

(5, 1).clue: This man brought the Roman alphabet & Latin literature to Ireland in the 400s A.D.

(6, 1).clue: Number of persons a love seat is designed for

(1, 2).clue: According to the Times, this show is "Ireland's answer to the Rockettes"

(2, 2).clue: This firm began in 1897 as Nippon Gakki Company, an organ manufacturer; electronic organs came along in 1959

(4, 2).clue: Nickname toted by baseball legend Leroy Paige who once advised, "Don't look back, something might be gaining on you"

(5, 2).clue: This sixth-largest country in the world was first sighted by Europeans in the 17th century

(6, 2).clue: We don't know how many faces death has, but a die has this many

(1, 3).clue: Reba McEntire said that this musical show she joined in 2001 felt like her life story because she's so similar to Annie Oakley

(2, 3).clue: This animal feed company began using its familiar red & white checkerboard trademark around 1900

(4, 3).clue: This "Round Mound of Rebound", also dubbed "Boy Gorge", was a first round pick of the '76ers in 1984

(5, 3).clue: About 35% of Bhutan's people are ethnically related to this small neighbor famous for its sherpas

(6, 3).clue: Number of legs on an orb weaver

(1, 4).clue: Ben Brantley said the Jetsons-style Egyptian outfits in this opera-inspired show "should top every drag queen's must-have list"

(2, 4).clue: Now a clothing retailer, it began in 1963 as a Chicago-based mail-order supplier of sailboat equipment

(4, 4).clue: Nickname of 5'10" Harold Henry Reese of the Brooklyn Dodgers

(5, 4).clue: Until the 1980s the city of Harare in this country was known as Salisbury

(6, 4).clue: Number of "Summits" in a climbing feat first completed in 1985

(1, 5).clue: Maxmillan Schell talked to the Times about his new role in the 2001 stage version of this film that won him an Oscar

(2, 5).clue: Named for its 2 owners, it introduced the first commercial drink mixer in 1911

(4, 5).clue: His Hockey Hall of Fame dad was "The Golden Jet" so naturally, this Dallas Star is known as "The Golden Brett"

(5, 5).clue: You'll find this 5,130-square-mile lake in Northwest Venezuela

(6, 5).clue: Used for self-understanding, the enneagram is a diagram showing this many personality types

(0, 0).clue: This expression comes from a 1956 novel about Frank Skeffington's final run for mayor
